required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study on TIL for the Treatment of r/r Gynecologic Tumors
clinical_study.official_title: A Clinical Safety and Efficacy Study on TIL for the Treatment of r/r Gynecologic Tumors

brief_summary.textblock: This study is to investigate the safety and efficacy of tumor infiltrating lymphocyte (TIL) therapy in patients with malignant refractory/relapsed gynecologic tumors. Autologous TILs are expanded from tumor resections or biopsies and infused i.v. into the patient after NMA lymphodepletion treatment with fludarabine and cyclophosphamide.

primary_outcome.description: To evaluate the efficacy of TIL infusion in patients as determined by objective response rate (ORR), which contains complete response (CR) and partial response (PR), using the RECIST v1.1, as assessed by the Investigator. ( CT Scan at 4-6 weeks after TIL infusion, and than every 4-6 weeks for 1 year, and then every six months after that for up to 3 years)
Percentage of patients that meet CR, PR and SD criteria set in this study according to RECIST 1.1
The time length between the first confirmed objective response per RECIST 1.1 to the treatment and the subsequent disease progression per RECIST 1.1
The time length between TIL infusion and confirmed subsequent disease progression according to RECIST 1.1
The length of time from the date of the start of TIL treatment that the patients are still alive

secondary_outcome.description: Patients with complete response per RECIST 1.1 to TIL treatment
Percentage of patients with partial response per RECIST 1.1 to TIL treatment
Patients with stable disease per RECIST 1.1 to TIL treatment
Patients with progressive disease per RECIST 1.1 to TIL treatment
Comparison of patients' quality of life before and after TIL treatment

arm_group.description: 1x10^9-3x10^11 in vitro expanded autologous TILs will be infused i.v. to patients with relapsed/refractory malignant gynecological tumors after NMA lymphodepletion treatment with fludarabine and cyclophosphamide. PD-1 checkpoint inhibitor would be applied as combination treatment to those patients.

intervention.description: Adoptive transfer of 1x10^9-3x10^11 autologous TILs to patients i.v. in 30-120 minutes.

eligibility.gender_description: This study is biologically possible only for females regardless of self-recognition of gender identity.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Director of Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics
